results.title: Jump the fence
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School, Natalie Green and Lucy MacLaren
results.brief_description: Two young girls who feel restricted at home decide to escape in a gelati van. After a short burst of freedom they end up in Winlaton, a girls’ training centre.

results.title: Jump shot from the dribble
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basketball Skills”.
One in a series of films on basketball skills, giving instruction and demonstration of basketball techniques, including slow-motion action and training routines. Narrated by Ron Pickering.

results.title: Jump rope
results.creator_credit: Pyramid Films, Computer Image and Robert Primes
results.brief_description: The camera zooms slowly in on a zoetrope featuring the stationary figure of a girl with a jump-rope. The zoetrope begins t turn and the jumping figure dissolves into life-enchanting, super-slow motion shots of young people jumping ropes. One unusual sequence views a jumper from below. Sequences employing multiple exposure and special computer techniques are used in demonstrating the healthful benefits of rope jumping.

results.title: Jump jet
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation and Derek Smith
results.brief_description: The aeroplane was invented in the early 1900s. Since then there have been only three major breakthroughs in aviation: the jet, the helicopter, and the jump jet. Traces the development of the vertical take-off jet in Britain, with some reference to developments in other countries. Narrated by Richard Maddock.

results.title: Julius Caesar: the rise of the Roman Empire
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and William Deneen
results.brief_description: The role of Julius Caesar in transforming Rome from a city Republic to a world empire; the arrest of power from the Senate by the triumvirate; Caesar’s military conquests culminating in his emergence as the single ruler of the Empire. He inaugurated reforms of the legal system, economy and public works. In 44 BC Julius Caesar was murdered.

results.title: Julius Caesar: an introduction
results.creator_credit: Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Peter Seabourne
results.brief_description: A talented English company performs key scenes in this abbreviated version which, however, preserves the sense of tragedy of the full-length drama. Brief narrative bridges connect the scenes, which offers the first-time reader an opportunity to acquire a grasp of the main themes and action, and enrich his understanding and appreciation of the play.

results.title: Julius Caesar and the Battle of Alesia
results.creator_credit: Phil Grabsky and Seventh Art Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Great commanders”.
Julius Caesar was a brilliant politician and military tactician. He used his power to shape the history of ancient Rome. Massively in debt, he led his armies through a decade of conquest in a bid for wealth, glory and power. Julius conquered not only Gaul but the Celts and Britons. At the Battle of Alesia he won against a force outnumbering him 5 to 1.

results.title: Julius Caesar [Excerpts]
results.brief_description: So that people who have had no opportunity of seeing Shakespeare’s plays staged may see leading English actors in a full-scale stage production, these excerpts from “Julius Caesar” have been filmed, sponsored by the British Council. The cast includes Leo Genn as Marc Antony; Felix Aylmer as Brutus; and John Slater, Emrys Jones, Frederick Cooper, Ben Williams, Grqace Allardyce, Arthur Hambling and Sydney Monckton among the other players.

results.title: Julius Caesar (Heston/Gielgud)
results.creator_credit: Peter Snell, Commonwealth United, Republic Pictures Corporation and Stuart Burge
results.brief_description: Shakespeare’s epic tragedy is brought to the screen in this British production with an all-star cast. Charlton Heston stars as Mark Antony, John Gielgud as Caeser and Jason Robards as Brutus. Opposed to the growing power of Caeser, and the fear that he poses a threat to the republican liberty of Rome, a group of senators conspire to murder him. The ringleaders, Cassius (Richard Johnson), and Casca (Robert Vaughn), convince the moderate Brutus to carry out their plan on the steps of the Senate. Mark Antony’s famous and stirring funeral oration incites the Roman populus to bring the perpetrators to justice. Richard Chamberlain also co-stars as Octavius Caeser, who avenges Caeser’s death in a battle with Cassius and Brutus.
